Clarity.Feedback: The learning objectives are not well presented in some slides, for example, in chapter 4, there is no clear instruction on the requirement for students, such as what classification algorithm is a must to grasp, and what is an extensive learning target.

Measurability.Feedback: No explicit objective measurement is mentioned in each chapter's main content of the slides.

Appropriateness.Feedback: In the description of the learning objectives, should include the examples: Articulate data mining principles, such as ....

Structure.Feedback: Syllabus articulates the requirements in a well-organized way, potential improvements: do not fake a name and email, you should leave a space for real professor to fill in their email and name, otherwise, it could be posted wrongly by mistake.

Coverage.Feedback: Good coverage, please insert some of the off-class learning material links such as Google Drive, etc.

Accessibility.Feedback: Well listed for the background requirements and pre-requests.

Transparency of Policies.Feedback: In the Academic Integrity, please cite the school's website or leave a space for instructor to link to the school's requirement.

Alignment.Feedback: There lacks the in-class practices, the class will be less interactive and cannot guarantee or examine the learning outcome of students.

Appropriateness.Feedback: The content directly goes to the concept, no connection with real-world examples, the design should start with real-world cases and then dive into the core concept and solutions.

Accuracy.Feedback: 1. Some slides contain raw .md syntax, for example: in the final version: **R.** is presented, not a well-compiled text-only format (such as p5 in chapter 1). 2. Some text is not framed inside the slide, spanning out of the allowed page size, especially when writing code examples (such as p23 in chapter 1, p29 in chapter 1, p9 in chapter 2, etc.). 3. Not matched well, please pay attention to font size and the word amount per page; sometimes words are too many and cannot be placed appropriately.

Alignment.Feedback: A major issue is, when beginning a topic, there lacks the reasons or prompts for students to understand why a topic is introduced. For example, in chapter 15, 'First, let's talk about Reinforcement of Learning.' Before that, there is no explanation of what reinforcement of learning is.

Coherence.Feedback: The logic sometimes is not coherent, the course review instructions are too rigid, do not sound like real professor instructions, and in the feedback section, it is mixed with technical details, not consistent.

Engagement.Feedback: Few examples are used, not connected with real-world scenarios, the format and style of the slide are too plain, not interesting.

Alignment.Feedback: The quizzes and exams can reflect the learning objectives, but need more formats of question types, now mainly focused on single-choice problems.

Clarity.Feedback: There is no rubric for the Discussion Questions; even though they are open-ended questions, there still needs to be some high-level instructions or expectations.

Formative Feedback.Feedback: The assessment is generated only for a whole class's slide, should insert it into the concepts inside the slide.

Variety.Feedback: The questions are relatively diverse, including single-choice, discussions, and activities, but it might be good to set some competing questions, such as for fastest solvers, or for most challenging questions, to trigger students' competition and motivate them to learn.

Coherence.Feedback: The content in each chapter overlaps, repetitive issues, and mis-inserted contents.

Alignment.Feedback: Those existed in the slide align with the overall learning objectives, but could be redundant, and some slide quality is not good enough for practice purposes.

Usability.Feedback: It is better to have page numbers included in the script; this will help teachers to navigate.
